He served in the [[South Carolina Legislature]] and was the [[List of Governors of South Carolina|66th]] [[Governor of South Carolina|governor]] of the state.
==Early life and education == [[File:Governor James Hopkins Adams of South Carolina bw.jpg|thumb|Governor James Hopkins Adams of South Carolina.]] Adams was born in Minervaville, South Carolina, in 1812 to Henry Walker Adams and Mary Goodwyn Adams.<ref name="ISBN 0837932017 p2"/> Both of his parents had died by the time James was three years old, and therefore he was raised by his grandfather, [[Joel Adams]], the patriarch of the Adams family of [[South Carolina]]. He graduated from [[Yale College]] in 1831.<ref name="ISBN 0837932017 p2"/>
==Career == In 1832, he joined the South Carolina [[Nullification Crisis|Nullification]] Convention which deliberated until 1833 on whether states could nullify federal laws. He was an opponent of nullification.
He was a member of the [[South Carolina House of Representatives]] from 1834 to 1837, 1840 to 1841, and 1848 to 1849. In 1850, he was elected to the [[South Carolina Senate]], where he stayed through 1853. He served as a brigadier general of the South Carolina Militia.<ref name="sciway.com">{{cite news |url=http://www.sciway.net/hist/governors/adams.html |title=Governor James Hopkins Adams |work=sciway.com |accessdate=November 13, 2013}}</ref>
In 1854, Adams was elected the [[List of Governors of South Carolina|66th]] [[Governor of South Carolina]], a position he held through 1857. In 1856, he recommended a resumption of the foreign slave trade as a way of eliminating illicit trade. The legislature rejected this proposal.
He signed the articles of secession for South Carolina, The [[Ordinance of Secession]], and served as a member of the commission to the United States government to negotiate the transfer of United States property in South Carolina to the state government.
==Personal life == He married Jane Margaret Scott in April 1832.<ref name="ISBN 0837932017 p2"/> They had 11 children. Among his many children was Lt. Colonel [[Warren Adams]], of the [[Confederate States Army]], who was in command of [[Battery Wagner]], South Carolina during the [[American Civil War]].<ref name="bellsouthpwp2.net">{{cite news |url=http://bellsouthpwp2.net/w/i/wifuha/heyward/c222s1.htm |title=Lt. Colonel Warren Adams |work=bellsouthpwp2.net |accessdate=November 13, 2013}}</ref>
==Death and legacy== He died in [[Columbia, South Carolina]], on July 13, 1861,<ref name="ISBN 0837932017 p2"/> and his remains were buried in Congaree, South Carolina.
